factoid: Outside there was the same cold stillness.
Outside there was the same moon.
The moon was brighter than before.
The light was strong.
The snow sparkled with so many stars.
One did not wish to look up at the sky.
The real stars were unnoticed.
The sky was black and dreary.
The earth was gay.
Nicholas thought, "I am a fool, a fool! What have I been waiting for?".
Nicholas ran out from the porch.
Nicholas went around the corner of the house.
Nicholas went along the path that led to the back porch.
Nicholas knew that Sónya would pass that way.
There were snow-covered piles of firewood halfway along the path.
Shadows from bare old lime trees fell on the snow and on the path.
The path led to the barn.
The barn had log walls.
The barn had a snow-covered roof.
The roof looked as if hewn out of some precious stone.
The roof sparkled in the moonlight.
A tree in the garden snapped with the frost.
All was again perfectly silent.
Nicholas's bosom seemed to inhale the strength of eternal youth and gladness.
The sound of feet descending the steps came from the back porch.
The bottom step had snow and gave a ringing creak.
An old maidservant said, "Straight, straight, along the path, Miss. Only, don’t look back."
Sónya answered, "I am not afraid."
The crunching, whistling sound of Sónya's feet in thin shoes came along the path toward Nicholas.
Sónya came along wrapped in her cloak.
Sónya was a couple of paces away when she saw Nicholas.
To Sónya, Nicholas was not the same as she had known and always slightly feared.
Nicholas was wearing a woman's dress.
Nicholas had tousled hair.
Nicholas had a happy smile new to Sónya.
Sónya ran rapidly toward Nicholas.
Nicholas thought, "Quite different and yet the same."
Nicholas looked at Sónya's face lit up by moonlight.
Nicholas slipped his arms under Sónya's cloak.
Nicholas embraced Sónya.
Nicholas pressed Sónya to him.
Nicholas kissed Sónya on the lips that had a smell of burnt cork.
Sónya kissed Nicholas fully on the lips.
Sónya disengaged her hands and pressed them to Nicholas's cheeks.
They said, "Sónya!... Nicholas!"
They ran to the barn.
They ran back again.
They re-entered the barn, with Nicholas by the front and Sónya by the back porch.
They all drove back from Pelagéya Danílovna’s.
Natásha always saw and noticed everything.
Natásha arranged that she and Madame Schoss should go back in the sleigh with Dimmler.
Natásha arranged that Sónya with Nicholas and the maids should go back.
Nicholas drove at a steady pace on the way back.
Nicholas kept peering at Sónya's face.
Nicholas searched beneath Sónya's eyebrows and mustache for his former and present Sónya.
Nicholas had resolved never to be separated from Sónya again.
Nicholas looked and recognized in Sónya both the old and new Sónya.
Nicholas was reminded by the smell of burnt cork of Sónya's kiss.
Nicholas inhaled the frosty air with a full breast.
Nicholas looked at the ground flying beneath him.
Nicholas looked at the sparkling sky.
Nicholas felt himself again in fairyland.
Nicholas asked Sónya, "Sónya, is it well with thee?"
Sónya replied, "Yes!"
Sónya asked, "And with thee?"
Nicholas handed the reins to the coachman.
Nicholas ran for a moment to Natásha's sleigh.
Nicholas stood on the wing of Natásha's sleigh.
Nicholas whispered in French, "Natásha!"
Nicholas asked, "Do you know I have made up my mind about Sónya?"
Natásha asked, "Have you told her?"
Natásha was suddenly beaming all over with joy.
Natásha said, "Oh, how strange you are with that mustache and those eyebrows!"
Natásha asked, "Are you glad?"
Natásha said, "I am so glad, so glad! I was beginning to be vexed with you."
Natásha said, "I did not tell you, but you have been treating her badly."
Natásha said, "What a heart she has, Nicholas!"
Natásha said, "I am horrid sometimes, but I was ashamed to be happy while Sónya was not."
Natásha said, "Now I am so glad! Well, run back to her."
Nicholas said, "No, wait a bit.... Oh, how funny you look!"
